title: How many seats in the Assembly of the Republic will the Socialist Party win in the next Portuguese parliamentary election?
preds:
I used the seat calculator where you can play with the numbers with the latest poll, it gets me to 103 seats. 
For Sunday, If PSD reaches 31.5 and PS doesn't beat 37% PS won't probably make 106.
https://tiagotvv.github.io/app/vote.html
The latest other poll gives them 95/105
https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/eleicoes-legislativas-2022/sondagem-da-universidade-catolica-ps-cai-mas-segura-maioria-de-36-face-a-psd-estacionado-nos-33_n1380060
Have to make choices here, I am again putting overweight in bucket 2.

I know very little about Portuguese politics. Looking at the polls leading up to the Oct 2019 election and those leading up to this one, the parties seem to be in much the same position. Portugal seems to have a high vaccination rate which indicates public trust in the government's response to the pandemic. The election is soon after the last one so the political scene may not have changed enough for voters to have changed their view over the direction of the country under the current government. At the moment I am guessing that the result will be similar to the previous election for the PS.

as @wackiewim points out, the D'Hondt method makes this election likely closer than it first appears with the vote spread between the two parties being narrowed. At this point I think it's still slightly more likely to be 106 or over but it's very close. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D%27Hondt_method#:~:text=Proportional%20representation%20systems%20aim%20to,the%20number%20of%20votes%20received.&text=The%20D'Hondt%20method%20minimizes,votes%20are%20represented%20exactly%20proportionally.

Update
Latest polls show a strong narrowing.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_Portuguese_legislative_election The D'Hondt conversion method means that if the gap between #1 and #2 reduces, that #1 picks up less seats, even if #1 has the same % of votes vs the previous election. 
In essence seems like PS is now polling to lose % vs last election. 
The gap with nr.2 in previous elections was 8.5%, in recent polls the gap narrows to <5%
Latest range is 99-110 seats for 37% of vote. Two latest polls have them end lower than 37%.
Second placed increases poll% to 32-33% All by all, chance that they lose seats vs 2019 is very realistic and it takes only 4 seat losses to move to bucket 2.
Switched the buckets to overweight bucket 2.

The D'Hondt conversion method means that if the gap between #1 and #2 reduces, that #1 picks up less seats, even if #1 has the same % of votes vs the previous election.
In essence seems like PS is polling in the similar range with upwards vector vs 2019. 
The gap with nr.2 in previous elections was 8.5%, in recent polls the gap was less until the latest polls, where the gap increased again to even 9%
Latest range is 104-113 seats for PS which would give it 80% pot 3. There is some correction possible though. Undecided voters, apparently could be turning out to increase CHEGA seats - latest poll 6-12 seats, so basically pick towards 10. Also the PPD could end up a bit higher (trend) and pick up on upper range 81-89 seats. So I can see in total swing of 6-8 seats away from PS, which leaves 104-108.
with 2 /5 on pot 2 and 3/5 on pot 3. https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/politica/legislativas-2022-sondagem-da-catolica-aponta-para-socialistas-a-frente-com-39-dos-votos_n1376526

Seems to me like the combination of a stronger PSD vote and Chega improving massively from 2019 can easily lead to a net decrease in PS seats. However, it is balancing on a knives edge, and given the nature of the election, leader perceptions will be key for valence voters - will be following changes following TV debates closely.

D'Hondt system of vote translation into seats means that when the smaller parties score lower % its more difficult for them to pick up seats.  Recent projection give them in general less % (-3% vs 2019). As such, the two biggest parties probably will pick up more seats together. Seems like PS and PPD are growing towards eachother which would cost PS despite having same %. The trend is going down for PS, so there is a reasonable chance that they will lose more than 2 seats net. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D%27Hondt_method

PS's polling has been quite consistent over the last several years but took a drop this past fall. 108 seats in 2019 with 36.3% of the vote (1,903,687), a gain of 22 seats. PSD won 79 seats with 27.8% of the vote (1,454,283), a loss of 10 seats. "The turnout in this election was the lowest ever in a general election in Portugal, with just 48.6% of registered voters casting a ballot." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Portuguese_legislative_election). PS is polling roughly on par with 2019, PSD is up 2%. "In the most recent national elections in the EU, the POLITICO Poll of Polls showed its worth. While the average polling miss for individual polls in our database is around 2.3 percentage points, the average difference between the election result of a party and our final POLITICO Poll of Polls is around 1.8 percentage points." https://www.politico.eu/article/how-politico-poll-of-polls-tracks-polling-trends-across-europe/ So the data should be pretty accurate. It's sounding surprisingly similar to Canada's election, where a minority government called an early election and the result was the status quo. It doesn't necessarily give them a strong mandate but it points out that no one else has any more trust so might as well stick with the devil they know. At this point I'd be surprised to see a swing of more than 5 seats, but that puts bin 2 and 3 both in play. PSD will likely gain a couple seats but it's unclear if those will come at the expense of PS. I'd be surprised to see a majority as there hasn't been one since 2005 and PS needed 45% of the popular vote to achieve that, a popularity they're far from currently having.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_Portuguese_legislative_election
They have 108 now - The polls are slightly worse now....so....
#JGS

The race is starting to heat up and Costa is still leading. However, Rio is rising in the polls and so is Ventura (now in third place). So at this point I expect Costa to end a bit lower than in 2019 (36+ %).

Using current seats as a basis, then given the Socialists made the call for new elections indicates they have data that they can win a modest increase in seats. There’s some chance that they’ve miscalculated (plus unexpected events in next month).
The rejection of the Socialist Party’s proposed budget is the reason for the January 2022 election. They are expected to loose seats. They currently hold 108 of the 230.

They have 106 now - The polls are slightly better....so....
#JGS
